title: Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis
setup_script: A 35-year-old man with a history of ulcerative colitis presents with fatigue, pruritus, and elevated liver enzymes. He denies alcohol use. On physical exam, he is in no acute distress but reports persistent itching. How would you proceed with this patient?

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 118/75 mmHg, HR 90 bpm, RR 16/min, Temp 36.6 °C.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident orders liver function tests
dynamic_flow.reply: Alkaline phosphatase and gamma-glutamyl transferase are elevated. Bilirubin is mildly elevated. AST/ALT are normal to mildly elevated.
MRCP demonstrates multifocal strictures and segmental dilatations of intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts, producing a beaded appearance.
Findings are consistent with primary sclerosing cholangitis.
There is no curative medical therapy. Pruritus can be treated symptomatically with cholestyramine. Fat-soluble vitamin levels should be monitored.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident addresses surveillance for complications
dynamic_flow.reply: Annual MRCP or ultrasound and CA 19-9 screening are recommended due to risk of cholangiocarcinoma.
Patients with PSC and ulcerative colitis require colonoscopy every 1–2 years due to increased risk of colorectal cancer.
Symptomatic dominant strictures can be managed with endoscopic dilation and stenting.
Liver transplantation is indicated in cases of liver failure, recurrent cholangitis, or intractable pruritus.
Median survival from diagnosis is approximately 10–15 years without transplantation.
Counseling includes vaccination against hepatitis A and B and avoidance of hepatotoxic medications.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about research/clinical trials
dynamic_flow.reply: Referral to a hepatology center for investigational therapies (e.g., high-dose ursodeoxycholic acid, obeticholic acid) may be considered.

critical_decision_points: Recognition of PSC diagnosis using cholestatic labs and MRCP findings
Awareness that no curative medical therapy exists; focus on symptomatic management
Screening for complications such as cholangiocarcinoma and colorectal cancer
Recognition of indications for liver transplantation
Patient education including vaccination and avoidance of hepatotoxins

rubric.resident_feedback_template: Strengths: You demonstrated strong diagnostic reasoning by recognizing PSC using both laboratory and imaging findings. You appropriately emphasized long-term surveillance and identified the importance of colonoscopy in the setting of ulcerative colitis. Communication of your plan was clear and structured. Areas for Improvement: Earlier recognition of the role of cholangiocarcinoma screening and the specific criteria for liver transplantation would improve your management approach. Greater emphasis on patient counseling regarding lifestyle modifications and hepatotoxin avoidance is recommended. Suggested Reading Topics: - Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis (SCORE curriculum) - Surveillance for Cholangiocarcinoma (ACS/ASE Review Manual) - Indications for Liver Transplantation in Chronic Liver Disease
